document.masterDocTitle: A revision of Leydigia Kurz, 1875 (Anomopoda, Cladocera, Branchiopoda), and subgeneric differentiation within the genus

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A revision of Leydigia Kurz, 1875 (Anomopoda, Cladocera, Branchiopoda), and subgeneric differentiation within the genus

heading.emphasis:
X.
Leydigia ( Neoleydigia ) cf. ipojucae Brehm, 1938

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Leydigia ipojucae Brehm, 1938 , p. 102
–103, figs 9–10;
Smirnov 1971 , p. 463
, fig. 580 (after Brehm, 1938 )

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type locality.
"Rio Ipojuca bei São Caetano. (Mun. São Caetano.)" There is a series of localities with this name in Brazil
,
but, most probably, samples were collected in the vicinity of São Caitano da Raposa (appr. 8º20'S , 36º06'W ), Municipio São Caitano (or Caetano ), State of Pernambuco , Brazil
.

Material examined.
Brazil .
Rio Grande do Norte :
3 parth. ♀♀ from a reservoir in semiarid NE Brazil , hatched from dried mud by C. Crispim , tube AAK 1999-098 ( 06º12'03''S , 36º49'87''W)
.
Size. Juvenile and adult parthenogenetic females from Rio Grande do Norte 510–900 µm (n = 3), range clearly under-estimated.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 338–349.
Leydigia cf. ipojucae
, parthenogenetic female from a reservoir in semiarid NE Brazil, Rio Grande do Norte, hatched from dried mud by C. Crispim. 338 – 339. Adult in lateral and anterior view. 340. Juvenile. 341 – 343. Head shield and dorsal head pores of adult. 344 – 345. Labrum. 346 – 349. Reticulation of valves, armature of its ventral, postero-ventral and posterior margin. Scale bar denotes 100 µm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Differential diagnosis. Setules in lateral groups on the labral keel longer and more robust than those on the anterior keel margin in
L. ipojucae
and are unique within the genus. Among the
acanthocercoides
-group, this is the only species with smooth hillocks on the preanal margin of the postabdomen. Also, only in this species and
L. striatadoes
scraper 1 on limb II have a setulated base.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 350–364.
Leydigia cf. ipojucae
, parthenogenetic female from a reservoir in semiarid NE Brazil. 350. Postabdomen of juvenile. 351 – 352. Postabdomen of adult. 353 – 354. Its preanal margin. 355 – 356. Armature of its postanal margin. 357. Series of setules at basal portion of preanal margin, cross section. 358 – 360. Distal portion of postabdomen, postabdominal claw in inner view and denticle in middle of claw on its posterior face. 361 – 362. Antenna I. 363 – 364. Antenna II and its apical swimming seta. Scale bar denotes 100 µm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Taxonomical comments. Although the description of Brehm (1938) occupied a page of text, it was inadequate. His reference to an 'identical' form from Argentina in Richard's (1897) article is not convincing. We can extract only the following information about Brehm’s species from his text: (1) body shape similar to that of
L. propinqua Sars, 1903
(I am sure that the author had no clear idea of the morphology of
propinqua
s. str. ); (2) eye and ocellus of similar size; (3) valves with dots and small-scale striation; (4) five groups of long setules on vetral margin of labrum; (5) small basal spine on postabdominal claw; (6) each lateral fascicle on postabdomen consists of a long seta, and a series of small, fine setules. In the author’s illustration it is shown, that (7) the postero-dorsal angle is ill-defined in
L. ipojucae
. Four transverse rows of setules, described in detail by Brehm, are present in all species of the genus.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 365–375.
Leydigia cf. ipojucae
, limbs of parthenogenetic female from a reservoir in semiarid NE Brazil. 365 – 366. Limb I and its distal portion. 367 – 368. Limb II and its gnathobase. 369 – 371. Limb III, largest seta of its exopodite, and inner limb portion. 372 – 373. Limb IV and its inner portion. 374 – 375. Limb V and its gnathobase. Scale bar denotes 100 µm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Brehm’s distinction of
L. ipojuca
from
L. propinqua
was based on dubious characters. The latter is a distinctive species, which has several other traits that are unique within the genus.
Leydigia ipojucae
is an
acanthocercoides
-like species, described earlier than other tropical
acanthocercoides
-like forms,
L. ciliata Gauthier, 1939
and
L. striata Birabén, 1939
, which are the most common tropical species of
Leydigia
( Frey 1982 ; Smirnov & Timms 1983 ;
Dumont et al. 1984
;
Kotov et al. 2003b
).

I think that Brehm explained incorrectly the armature of the labrum in his species. In
L. ipojucae
the long and stout lateral setules project behind the margin, while the marginal setae are finer and significantly shorter, and were, to my mind, missed by him. I have not seen in original samples or previous publications, any other species from anywhere in the world with groups of stout 'spines' on the labrum, which setulation is one of the most important traits for the systematics of
Leydigia
. The bulk of earlier published descriptions of South American forms dealt with
L. striata
, which is relatively common there ( Birabén 1939 ;
Kotov et al . 2003b
). Also,
L. schubarti Brehm and Thomsen, 1936
was described from this continent, but it lacks these setules.

Among the many difficulties in understanding Brehm’s taxa is the fact that he did not specify types. Few Brehm's specimen tubes survived in the collection of Vienna University, in disorder (H. Loeffler, personal communication through H. J. Dumont). No types are present here, but there remains a slight chance of finding some original samples with Brehm’s species, that colud be used for the selection of lectotypes . This is a problem for the future selection of neotypes .
Distribution. A few localities in Brazil .
